As Quickstride and Straight Shot get Rodimus out of Tucson, the new Autobot=
 leader now finds it possible to transform into his robot mode and now assi=
sts in the digging of the tunnel.

"Good idea Perceptor, I'll help you dig =
so that the burden doesn't all fall on you."

--- In nbwrpg@yahoogroups.com=
, <airly2002@...> wrote:
>
> Perceptor:
> 
> "Follow me"said dryly the male=
 he left Tucson and transformed to his beast 
> mode he started to dig quic=
kly as he can a tunned in order to they can ride 
> towards the surface.
> =

e do as instructed by Perceptor, and instead

ads off Rodimus, they try to scan for signs of

n comming from internal scanners, Straight Shot 
> > nodds, and indeed pick=
s up a faint sign of life from within the cocoon 
> > surrounding Rodimus.
=
> >
> > " It's faint Perceptor but he is alive.  And appears to be stable."=

good at 
> > this point.
> >
> > " I'm sorry, but I will not be able to car=
ry everyone to the surface. it's 
> > a straight climb up without proper fo=
ot holds, or ramps.  I'll have to

here.  Straight Shot, you're small

y.  I'll lend you a towe line so you

rest of us."

> Tucson opens his doors to let everyone out.  Quickstride now helps to get=

airly2002@> wrote:

> >> Kup:
> >>
> >> Kup smiled back and waited for =
more news
> >>
> >> --------------------------------------------------
> >>=
 From: "Preston Carroll" <supercyclonus@>
> >> Sent: Wednesday, June 02, 20=
10 11:26 AM
> >> To: <nbwrpg@yahoogroups.com>
> >> Subject: Re: Into the Da=
rkness
> >>
> >> > The trip through the tunnel is relatively straight, with=
 only very
> >> > slight turns here and there as the rather large miussile =
truck revs
> >> > its engines and pushes its way through, leaving behind th=
e insectile
> >> > creatures as well as the two sweeps that had been captur=
ed by them as
> >> > well.
> >> >
> >> > As Quickstride and Straightstride =
try to pull off the sticky cable the
> >> > realize that the cable is more =
than stuck to Rodimus, but its actually
> >> > attatced. In fact Rodimus' f=
orm cannot be truly seen, as he's covered
> >> > head to foot in them, howe=
ver every scan confirms that he is indeed in
> >> > there somewhere. Scans =
also reveal that although he is healthy, he is
> >> > undergoiong his own o=
rdeal, something left over from the insects. Time
> >> > is of the essence =
to get him back and repaired.
> >> >
> >> > As the party makes it way back =
to the Ark they can hear several
> >> > explosions behind them, the walls r=
umbling around them but so far
> >> > nothing seems to inhibit their travel=
.
> >> >
> >> > Meanwhile back at the Ark Lord Elder was there at the headq=
uarters,
> >> > apparently he had not taken any time for rest or even to ea=
t, instead
> >> > he manned the communicatyion station waiting for any word=
.
> >> >
> >> > "We read you Tuscon!" Elder said as the call came in. "We w=
ill have
> >> > medical staff standing by when you get here." Elder manipul=
ated a few
> >> > controls as he spoke, "and the shield is up and waiting f=
or your
> >> > entrance."
> >> >
> >> > Elder turned back to Kup and just s=
miled broadly, "They're alive!" he
> >> > said, nearly leaping out his chai=
r with happniness.
> >> >
> >> > It takes Tuscon hours of driving, but fina=
lly Tuscon arrives at an
> >> > opening, a final break in the long monotony=
 of near featureless
> >> > smoothly tunneled walls. They at long last arri=
ve at an opening to a
> >> > rather deep pit.
> >> >
> >> > The pit is very=
 deep and very dark and it seems to go on for a very
> >> > long time. It i=
s roughly 8-10 feet and looking down it runs nearly
> >> > straight down in=
to the depths of the earth; even with artificial
> >> > light, its end poin=
t cannot be seen as it continued into the darkness
> >> > below. However lo=
oking up, several hundred feet up a tiny pinprick of
> >> > light can be se=
en, it is the surface! However to reach the top one
> >> > would need to be=
 able to fly or have extremely good climbing
> >> > abilities, as there are=
 no hand holds and not even a single plant
> >> > breaks the surface of the=
 walls lining this area, the sides are
> >> > extremely smooth and sheer,
>=
 >> > almost as if someone had cut it with some sort of high energy beam. .=

> >> >
> >> > From beneath Tuscon's position heat and noxious fumes rise f=
rom below,
> >> > clearly show the danger of failing to climb or fly proper=
ly and
> >> > plunging into the super heated depths. It would be a grizzly =
end
> >> > indeed.
